) The purpose for developing emergency plans is to provide emergency man- agement guidelines for managers and employees to reduce the effects of incidents and emergencies that could harm employees and/or deny access or damage the facility. Information regarding emergency planning and response may be found in IRM
, Occupant Emergency Plan, and in di- rectives from the General Services Administration (GSA) and the Department of Homeland Security. (

) All employees should be aware of the Homeland Security Advisory System which uses color-coded alerts to indicate the general level of security. responses at each level will vary by locality and facility. (

) The Occupant Emergency Plan (OEP) provides guidance for employees to follow in the event of an emergency. It is designed to reduce the threat to personnel, property, and other assets within the office, building or facility. to the variety of sizes, locations and functions of facilities, it is impractical to develop a standard OEP suitable for all offices. (

) The servicing AWSS office coordinates the OEP for each location in tion with GSA and other resident federal agencies. The Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) will coordinate with AWSS for the quarters Office. In field offices, the F&M Office Manager will coordinate the OEP with AWSS after soliciting input from the Managing Counsel, and notify AWSS of subsequent changes. (

) On an annual basis, Office Managers, the Managing Counsel and Headquar- ters Administrative Officers will ensure that employees are familiar with the procedures in the OEP, and will ensure that copies of the OEP are available all employees. (

) When it is necessary for employees to leave the work area during an emergency, managers will implement the procedures in the OEP to safely evacuate employees. Each manager and the Managing Counsel will information off-site so that they are able to reach his/her direct reports and employees in an emergency. (
) Employees should be familiar with the OEP and know whom to call and actions to take in the event of an emergency. (

) The Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) participates with IRS in the refinement of the Continuity of Operations Plan (COOP) in accor- dance with federal mandates to ensure that Chief Counsel can continue to perform its significant functions during and after an emergency. (

) The COOP identifies responsibilities, information and procedures necessary ensure that Counsel and IRS essential functions continue in the event of an emergency situation which may disrupt or threaten the ability to operate in Washington, D.C. metropolitan area. The COOP focuses only on those functions that cannot be suspended for a
-day period without adversely affecting operations. (

) A Business Resumption Plan (BRP) is a guide for the orderly of operations after an incident which disrupts program operations. The Resumption tion may be caused by fires, natural disasters, or other critical emergencies. The objective of the plan is to resume processing of critical functions as quickly as possible and eventually return to full, normal operations. (

) The Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) has oversight of business recovery and business resumption operations throughout the of Chief Counsel and is responsible for coordinating the BRP with the IRS the Headquarters Office. (
) The F&M Area Managers are responsible for coordinating BRPs with the Matrix Area Team Leader and IRS organizations for posts of duty within jurisdiction. (

) IRS has established Senior Commissioner’s Representatives (SCR) and Ad- ministrative Officers who have the authority to make decisions regarding for Field closings within their jurisdiction. Based on the circumstances, IRS may take the position that local management may close the office “as appropriate”. These decisions are often, but not always, made in conjunction with the Federal Executive Board. The Managing Counsel in each POD has the authority to make all office closing decisions in Counsel field offices. When practical, the Managing Counsel will coordinate with the SCR or IRS trative Officer in making decisions on office closings. The decision to close apply to all employees at the site. (

) Under hazardous weather conditions, field offices will generally follow the of the local IRS office. Once a Managing Counsel has made a decision to close an office, the Office Manager is responsible for notifying appropriate Counsel(s) and the F&M Area Manager of emergency field office closings those individuals are responsible for notifying their chain of command. The Managing Counsel should inform the Matrix Area Team Leader. Notification should be made expeditiously, and can be by e-mail, phone, or fax. (

) Where the circumstance is limited to Counsel (e.g., there is a fire or other safety hazard in a building occupied only by Counsel, or electricity or is disrupted on Counsel’s floor), the Managing Counsel makes the decision about whether or not to close an office. The decision will be shared with the Matrix Area Team Leader. (

) When conditions call for the delayed opening of the office and/or leave policy, employees should notify their manager as soon as possible if Absences Due decide to remain at home for the entire day and use annual leave or leave without pay. (

) When emergency conditions exist and the office is not closed, managers will confer with the Managing Counsel. A manager may excuse an employee’s arrival, on an individual basis, without charge to leave or loss of pay. For detailed information regarding emergency conditions and bargaining unit employees, see Article

of the Counsel-NTEU contract. (

) If an employee’s continuing efforts to reach the office are unsuccessful due emergency conditions, the employee is expected to inform their manager of this situation as soon as possible. Managers will consult with the Managing Counsel in determining whether administrative leave can be used for part or of the employee’s absence. Managers will consider reasonably acceptable documentation provided by the employee that they made reasonable efforts reach the office. (
